article:
The '[[Los Angeles Dodgers]]' are the most successful franchise in the National
League and the second most successful and wealthy in Major League Baseball after
the New York Yankees. [http://www.forbes.com/teams/los-angeles-dodgers/ #2
Los Angeles Dodgers] The franchise was formerly based in Brooklyn and
known originally as the âGraysâ or âTrolley Dodgersâ after the trams which
supporters had to avoid to enter games. Arlott, John (editor);
The Oxford Companion to Sports and Games; p. 125. ISBN 0192115383 Later it
became known successives as the âBridegroomsâ, âSuperbasâ, âDodgersâ and
âRobinsâ; the present âDodgersâ was firmly established in 1932.

The franchise has won the World Series six times and lost a further twelve, and
like the Yankees and Cardinals have never lost 100 games in a season since World
War I, with their worst record since then being in 1992 with sixty three wins
and their best records ever being in 1953 with 105 wins and 1942 with 104. Their
most successful period, between 1947 and 1966 with ten World Series appearances
and only two seasons with 71 or more losses (one of them the year they moved to
Los Angeles after a dispute over stadium funding ), was
famous for the Dodgers becoming the first Major League Baseball team to
incorporate African American players, led by Jackie Robinson and Roy
Campanella.
categories: Major League Baseball teams seasons|Los Angeles Dodgers
